ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TAN WAH PIOW
(Illegal entry into United Kingdom)


    1. Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether he will ask the British Government for an explanation why it did not treat Tan Wah Piow as an illegal immigrant and did not deport him when it was known that he entered the United Kingdom on a forged document.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has pointed out in a diplomatic note to the British High Commission in Singapore that the British authorities had not taken action to deport Tan Wah Piow after it was known that he had entered the United Kingdom on falsified documents. The Ministry has requested an explanation of the reasons for this position and the present status of Tan Wah Piow which allows him to continue residing in the UK. A reply to the note is expected soon.

CASH GRANT FOR RESETTLED SHOPKEEPERS


    The following question stood in the name of Mr Heng Chiang Meng.

    2. To ask the Minister for National Development whether the new policy of giving a cash grant of $26,000 per premises to shopkeepers in temporary structures will be applicable to those shopkeepers already resettled but who are currently awaiting allocation of alternative shop accommodation.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Boon Teck): Question 2, Sir.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 31st December 1986, there were 80 shopkeepers in temporary structures who had been resettled and who were waiting for shops which they had requested. These 80 shopkeepers were offered HDB shops over the first seven months of this year. Fifty of them accepted shops which were allocated to them. The other 30 either did not

Column: 1522

respond to the letters asking them to select from a list of shops or they responded but were unsuccessful in obtaining the shops of their choice. They were given a last chance to accept an offer of shops prior to the policy announcement on 28th July 1987, but they turned it down. The new policy of cash compensation will not apply to these cases. Besides these, there are no other cases which fall into the category described by the Member.

    All other resettlement cases who were still staying on site on 28th July 1987, will be subject to the new policy, ie, they will be given cash compensation and no alternative shops on priority will be offered to them. They will, however, enjoy a preferential margin of 5% or 10% when they tender for HDB rental shops. It has always been the practice, whenever a change in Resettlement Policy is introduced, that the change is applied to those on whom clearance notices have been served but who are still on the site.

HDB RENTAL FLAT RELOCATION EXERCISE


    3. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for National Development whether, during the present rental flat relocation exercise, the Housing and Development Board was able to relocate all the tenants to nearby neighbourhood, as promised by his predecessor.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the experience so far shows that about 50% of the tenants affected by the relocation exercise take the opportunity to buy flats whilst the other 50% want to continue to rent HDB flats.

    For tenants who want to buy flats, the HDB will offer them new flats according to their preference in the Outer Suburban and New Town Zones where the majority of the new flats are available.

    As for tenants who want to continue to rent, vacant flats may not be available in the areas which they prefer. HDB will try its best to allocate the affected tenants alternative rental flats within the same estates. Where alternative rental flats in the same estate are fully taken up, the tenants will be allocated rental flats in neighbouring

Column: 1523

estates. The record to date shows that HDB has managed to allocate rental flats in the same or nearby estates to about 75% of the tenants who wanted to continue renting flats. The rest were allocated rental flats further away.

PRIMARY 1 REGISTRATION
(Enrolment Limit for Malay pupils)


    4. Encik Zulkifli bin Mohammed asked the Minister for Education what problems were encountered during the recent Primary 1 registration exercise pertaining to the 25% limit for Malay pupil enrolment and what steps his Ministry will take to rectify anomalies that have arisen, for example, parents not given the opportunity to register their child in the school where their elder child is studying.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    At the request of the Malay Members of Parliament, a limit of 25% was placed on the intake of Primary 1 Malay pupils in this year's Pre-primary and Primary 1 registration exercise. The main problem encountered in the exercise was that in certain geographical zones with a high concentration of Malays, some Malay children were unable to enrol in the neighbourhood schools of their choice. The Ministry will offer the unplaced Malay children places in schools nearest to the school of registration but which still have vacancies and are within the 25% limit. If parents prefer, they can opt for schools where their children are registered regardless of the 25% limit. The 25% limit did not apply to Malay children seeking admission under Phase 1 of the Pre-primary and Primary 1 registration exercise. If the Member for Eunos can give me details where this ruling has been violated, I shall look into this matter.

Column: 1523

ENROLMENT LIMIT FOR MALAY PUPILS
(Justification)


    5. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Education what studies have been made to justify limiting the enrolment of Malay students to 25% each school and

Column: 1524

whether such a policy will create other problems.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the Minister for Education): Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister again.

    Statistics show that Malay children in primary schools with a high concentration of Malay pupils performed poorly in PSLE as compared with their counterparts in schools with a lower proportion of Malay pupils. Where Malay pupils comprised 30% or more of the school enrolment, over one-third of them failed their PSLE. The failure rate among Malay pupils in schools where they formed not more than 10% of the school population was less than 20%.

    With regard to the second part of the question, I have dealt with the matter in my reply to the question from the Member for Eunos.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, it would appear that this policy is based purely on educational considerations. Has the Minister taken into account the cultural, social and other practical problems arising from this policy?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, this policy was taken up as a result of a request from the Malay Members of Parliament who are well acquainted with the failure rates as well as the success rates of Malay pupils in different schools.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, it is obvious that the Minister has not made a thorough study of this matter. Is the Minister now willing to carry out a study on whether there would be other problems when this policy is implemented?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not sure what the Member means that the Ministry has not made a thorough study of this matter. Perhaps he would like to bring out some instances of this.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, I was thinking whether or not it would disorientate the Malay students if you put them in smaller groups; whether they will feel more insecure. There are other problems arising. So I do not know whether the Ministry should go in-depth into this before they put a limit on a minority group.

Column: 1525



     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): I hope the Member for Potong Pasir understands that the school environment has an effect on the language pupils use in school. And in schools with a high concentration of Malay pupils the tendency is for them to speak in Malay. This is a natural thing to do. But if this is allowed to persist in a school, then their English will, in the long run, suffer.

    Language, Mr Speaker, Sir, is the key to the acquisition of knowledge. If a pupil is unable to understand a language, which in our case here is English, then he is unable to receive information or knowledge in that language. It is therefore very important, Sir, that this problem is met as soon as possible. What I would like to emphasize here again, Sir, is that over-concentration of people of one race in a particular place works against our racial harmony and social contact which are very essential in our multi-racial society.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I be allowed to reply? Just to say a few words.

     Mr Speaker: You are not allowed to reply, Mr Chiam.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: The Minister for the Environment has been given a chance to speak.

     Mr Speaker: You are allowed to ask supplementary questions. If you do not have any, do sit down.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: All right. May I ask the Minister this question. This problem is an educational problem. Does the Minister not think that they should deal with it in an educational way, ie, perhaps reduce the number of pupils in a class, or perhaps give the poorer pupils extra tuition? If this is an educational problem, then I think it should be tackled by educational methods and theories, and not to arbitrarily limit the enrolment of one minority group in a school. In other words, they would have lost the choice of their own school. I think you should tackle the problems correctly and not just arbitrarily stop the pupils from going to the school of their own choice.

    The other point is ---

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, where is your supplementary question?

Column: 1526



     Mr Chiam See Tong: --- that there is nothing to stop Malay pupils from gathering and speaking in Malay even if it is limited to 25%.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the points that the Member has made regarding smaller class sizes, remedial classes and so on, have been taken because these are measures which we are already implementing in our schools.

    As for a smaller group of Malay pupils in a school, there are schools today with enrolments of 5% or 10% Malay pupils.

     The Minister for Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Sir, may I be allowed to say a few words?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no question of limiting the choice of any pupil. If the Member has heard accurately the answer given by the Minister of State to the question from the Member for Eunos, then he would know that what we have done for those Malay children who have not been able to get a place in the school of registration at the first time because of the 25% limit is to offer them a place in a school as close as possible to their school of registration but where the 25% limit has not been reached. But if the parents prefer, as stated by my Minister of State, and provided the school of registration still has vacancies, then the parents can register their child and the child can go to the preferred school of registration. But the choice is up to the parents.

    As the Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs has already stated, there are sound educational grounds for limiting or lowering the enrolment of Malay Primary 1 children in schools. Where there are concentrations of Malay children, there is a natural tendency for them to gather together and to talk in Malay.

    I think, Mr Speaker, Sir, what the Member is suggesting will be detrimental to the interest of the Malay community, and particularly to the interest of the Malay children themselves. As he says, this is an educational problem. We are trying to deal with it in an educational way. Where there are other cultural problems, I am sure they

Column: 1527

will be looked into by my Ministry and by Mendaki with the assistance of the Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs.

    Much obliged, Mr Speaker, Sir.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: May I ask the Minister. He says that he has dealt with this problem from an educational point of view. Can he quote me instances where the failure rate in schools which have more than 30% Malay intake is fairly high? What educational methods have they used to solve this problem other than limiting the intake to 25%?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the answer has already been given by my Minister of State. I do not think we should repeat the answer again.

ADMISSION TO INDEPENDENT SCHOOLS
(Government assistance for needy pupils)


    6. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for Education how the establishment of independent schools will benefit other schools in Singapore and what measures will be taken to ensure that admission to the independent schools will be available to all children who qualify regardless of the financial circumstances.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has repeatedly explained that the establishment of independent schools will not be solely for the benefit of the children in these schools. The purpose of establishing independent schools is to have role models to enable us to see how the education system can be improved in order to help each pupil to realize his or her full potential. This, Sir, must be our ultimate objective.

    Independent schools can do many things. They will be able to innovate and introduce creative educational programmes with the minimum of bureaucracy. These innovations can then be extended to other schools. Also, in recruiting principals and teachers in a competitive market, independent schools will also help to set the market value of good principals and good teachers. This in turn will help us to determine what remuneration the Government must offer in order to attract good people to join the teaching service and, just as important, to retain them.

Column: 1528



    In providing quality education for their pupils, independent schools will therefore set high standards which will serve as benchmarks for schools in Singapore. In this way, the benefits of the independent schools can be spread throughout our whole education system.

    Now, Sir, admission to independent schools will not depend on the financial circumstances of parents or their ability to pay fees. To ensure that bright but needy children who cannot pay the fees are not denied admission to independent schools, the Government has set up a financial assistance scheme for these pupils. The Government will provide the full subsidy of school fees for pupils from families with a monthly household income of $800 or less or with a monthly household income per dependent child of $400 or less. There will also be a half-subsidy of school fees for pupils from families with a monthly household income of between $800 and $1,200 or a monthly household income per dependent child of between $400 and $600. Pupils can apply for financial assistance at any point in their school career and they will enjoy the assistance throughout their entire school career. They will also be eligible to apply for other assistance schemes.

    Sir, the independent schools are also setting up their own endowment funds which, among other objectives, will seek to provide financial assistance to needy pupils over and above that which is provided by the Government. The Government will encourage the establishment of these endowment funds by, first, making the donations to the endowment funds tax exempt and, secondly, making a start- up donation of $1 million on a dollar-for-dollar basis to each of the endowment funds.

    Sir, with the financial assistance provided by the Government and the further assistance to be provided by the endowment funds of the independent schools, there should be no doubt in anyone's mind that admission to the independent schools will be open to all pupils who qualify regardless of their financial circumstances.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, the Government support for the endowment funds is a very positive move.

Column: 1529

Can I ask the Minister whether the Government support for the independent schools' endowment fund will be extended to other schools which would like to set up their own funds, regardless of whether they are independent or Government?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member has asked a very important question which is a natural follow-up of his first question and I believe it deserves a careful answer. With your permission, Sir, I would like to read out the answer which I have prepared.

    The answer to the Member's supplementary question, Sir, is, in principle, yes, provided that the school comes up with a well-conceived plan for the management and for the use of the school's endowment fund. This would be open to other schools as well, not only the independent schools.

    Let me give you an example. Raffles Institution. The school has informed the Ministry that the majority of parents of RI students and the Old Rafflesians are of the view that Raffles Institution should build up an endowment fund to help defray the cost of improving RI's educational programmes before the school considers changing its present status as a Government school. With an endowment fund, RI would then be in a better position at some future date to decide whether or not to go independent.

    Consequently, the Old Rafflesians Association and the Raffles Institution School Advisory Committee have decided to take the necessary action to build up an endowment fund. I am happy to inform Members that the Government will support RI's efforts in the same way as for the independent schools.

USE OF DISPOSABLE CROCKERY
(Progress report)


    7. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for the Environment (a) if he will give a progress report on the pilot project to use disposable crockery in selected hawker centres; (b) whether hawkers will be allowed to revert to the use of normal

Column: 1530

crockery if the project proves to be unpopular; and (c) when will his Ministry enforce the use of disposable crockery in all hawker centres if it deems the project successful.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The Ministry introduced disposable crockery in five food centres in February this year. Since then, another six food centres have also joined in. Disposable crockery was introduced as a means to upgrade the cleanliness and standard of hygiene in our food centres. During the past six months, it has been observed that the 11 food centres using disposable crockery are much cleaner. They are better organized.

    In the past, before disposable crockery was introduced, it was common to see tables cluttered with soiled dishes and leftover food. A customer wanting to use the table would have to wait patiently for the stallholders to come and remove their respective crockery. It was also common to see stacks of soiled dishes and leftover food placed by the side of the stalls, against some pillar or wall, awaiting collection by the respective stallholders.

    Then there was the problem of washing. As it was, the stalls were already crowded with all sorts of cooking paraphernalia. Within the confined space, stallholders would have to prepare and cook their food. When they also had to scrap off the leftover food into a bin placed inside the stall and wash dishes within their stalls, it is not difficult to imagine the mess that was created. The crockery could not have been very thoroughly washed. All too often, the floor traps were choked with food scraps and the stalls were wet and dirty.

    With disposable crockery, we can have a very efficient system of clearing tables. Everything on the table goes straight into the trash bin. There is no more leftover food lying about, no more soiled crockery on the floor and no more washings within the stalls.

Column: 1531



    Some hawkers are not happy with the use of disposable crockery because it means slightly more operating costs to them. Cleanliness and hygiene may not be foremost in their minds. There is an increasing consumer demand for cleaner eating places. If food centres cannot be kept clean and hygienic, then they may eventually lose out to the cleaner restaurants, eating houses and private food centres.

    The Ministry is satisfied that the use of disposable crockery is very suited for food centres and the advantages far outweigh the disadvantages. The food centres that are now using disposable crockery will be required to continue to use disposable crockery. The Ministry will also be getting more food centres to use disposable crockery in the near future.

BUS AND TAXI FARES
(Position upon operation of MRT)


    8. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Communications and Information whether bus fares and taxi fares will be raised either in anticipation of or on the coming into operation of the Mass Rapid Transit system.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Transport Council Bill was recently debated and passed at the last sitting of this House and has since been enacted. One of the functions of the Council is to receive and consider applications on fares from bus and taxi operators. The Council in making its decision must safeguard the public's interest and also take into account the financial viability of the operators. So far, the Council has not received any application from taxi operators and bus operators.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, can the Minister assure the House that he will urge the operators to keep any fare changes to a minimum or, better still, not to have any fare increase at all?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry is always concerned with the welfare of the commuters and has already advised the operators to bear in mind the concerns of commuters and also to take

Column: 1532

into consideration the fact that the MRT system will be phased in over a period of some three years. Also, particularly at this time, the operators should also bear in mind the fact that our workers have voluntarily exercised wage restraint. The operators have assured the Ministry that they will bear these factors in mind when they conduct their studies which are currently near completion.

    Sir, I am confident that with the newly established Public Transport Council which will look after the interests of the commuters, the Council will not approve any increase unless there are justifications for it.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Can the Minister please tell this House when he thinks the new fare structures for the bus, taxis and MRT will be announced?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I mentioned in my reply that the studies are nearing completion. I expect them to provide the information to the public very soon.

TAX RELIEF FOR PROVIDING FINANCIAL CARE FOR SIBLINGS


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Heng Chiang Meng -

    9. Mr Heng Chiang Meng: To ask the Minister for Finance whether he will consider giving tax relief to persons providing financial care for their younger siblings in situations where their parents are unable to do so.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin: Question No. 9, Sir.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Jalan Kayu will no doubt be already aware that our income tax system is a progressive one. Reliefs, though necessary, are by its very nature regressive. Expanding on our present system of dependants' relief would merely allow taxpayers with higher assessable incomes to benefit more in comparison to the lower income groups. I do not therefore propose to consider further revisions to our present system of dependants' relief.

    A general reduction in our individual tax rates is a more equitable one. The Government has over the years sought to reduce the burden of the individual taxpayer. Our

Column: 1533

tax rates have been reduced five times during the Years of Assessment 1978, 1980, 1982, 1985 and 1987. The complementary policy of granting tax rebates has been practised from Assessment Year 1984.

ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY
(Labour shortage)


    10. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the rapid expansion in the labour-intensive electronics industry will create the same labour problems for Singapore as in the recent past when there were as many as 150,000 foreign workers in Singapore.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Singapore economy has recovered, more jobs have been created. Unemployment has declined from a peak of 6.5% in June last year to 4.7% in June this year. The electronics industry, whose output in the first half of this year increased by 35%, has created exceptionally many jobs. With further steady growth projected for the rest of 1987, there is a danger of a labour shortage resulting in job-hopping and high wage increases.

    Sir, inhalant abuse in Singapore was first detected in 1980. In that year, only 24 cases were detected. But inhalant abuse soon became a serious problem affecting mainly our young citizens. At the end of June this year, over a period of 7 1/2 years, the cumulative number detected was 3,302. Unless the problem is effectively contained early, it will soon become unmanageable.

    For the first half of this year, more inhalant abusers were detected compared to the corresponding period last year - an increase of 21.5%. The increasing trend is alarming and the spread of inhalant abuse must be checked. We have to ensure that it does not become the alternative to drug abuse.

    Besides the alarming growth in first-time inhalant abusers, there is also a corresponding increase in the number of repeaters detected each year, rising from 11% in 1982 to 27% in 1986.

    A survey of more than 3,000 abusers detected from 1980 to June 1987 showed that 21% of them were below 15 years of age and nearly 63% between the ages of 15 and 19. In other words, Sir, more than 83% of the abusers were under 20 years of age.

Other organs which can be affected include kidneys, lungs and the heart. Acute intoxication can also lead to "sudden sniffing death". Indeed, there have been 20 deaths related to inhalant abuse, with seven of these cases detected in the first half of this year alone. Whilst under intoxication, six persons drowned, three persons hung themselves, six persons fell off from tall buildings, one person was killed in a road accident and four persons died in other situations. In addition, 11 glue sniffers are known to have suffered permanent brain damage. The Central Narcotics Bureau has also detected several cases of violent behaviour which is associated with glue sniffing.

We did study the inhalant abuse legislation of other countries but they were not very helpful because they did not focus on the rehabilitative aspect. As was the case with the Misuse of Drugs Act, we are therefore breaking new ground.

    At the same time, Sir, we had to take care and to remember that we are dealing with young persons. Members will note therefore that there are two important aspects where the measures in this Bill differ significantly from the approach in the Misuse of Drugs Act. In the first place, a person detected as an inhalant abuser will not immediately be subject to compulsory treatment and rehabilitation but will be put on a supervision order. It is only a repeater and those who breach the supervision order who will undergo treatment and rehabilitation. A comparison under the Misuse of Drugs Act, as Members know, a first-time addict can be subject to compulsory treatment and rehabilitation.

    The second aspect which is different is that an inhalant abuser can be subject to compulsory treatment initially for a six-month period which can be extended by periods of three months but subject to a maximum of 12 months. Compared to the Misuse of Drugs Act, in that law, a drug

addict can be subjected to institutional treatment for 36 months.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the approach in this law may appear to be less strict and less harsh a regime but we believe, Sir, that putting the first-timer on a warning or notice period and subjecting only repeaters to treatment for a shorter period will be an effective approach.

    Another area which was problematic, Sir, was how to regulate the misuse by shops and retailers. The approach in the Misuse of Drugs Act, namely, a strict prohibition of sale of the substances, was impractical. Unlike heroin and other hard drugs, the chemical substances in the problem of inhalant abuse are just contained in too wide a variety of household, commercial and industrial products. We therefore, Sir, decided to make it an offence only for a person to supply or offer to supply an intoxicating substance where the supplier knows, or has reasonable cause to believe, that such substance is likely to be used or inhaled for the purposes of inducing or causing intoxication. This provision is adapted from a recent United Kingdom law. I wish to stress that the prosecution in such an instance will have to prove knowledge on the part of the supplier. It will therefore apply to those blatant cases where suppliers deliberately sell intoxicating substances to abusers for the purpose of inhalant abuse. The penalty is a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding two years or both. The Bill also empowers the Director, CNB, to obtain information relating to intoxicating substances.

    The Bill confers the necessary powers to the authorities to implement the provisions. A person suspected of being an inhalant abuser can be required to undergo a blood test. A person who has attained 16 years of age is deemed capable of giving consent. A presumption of abuse of an intoxicating substance will apply where the concentration of a chemical compound in the blood exceeds the amount specified in the Schedule.

supervision, the Director may place the person under a supervision order for a period of not more than a year. A person who is arrested for inhaling an intoxicating substance during or after the period of his supervison (in other words a repeater) can be ordered to be admitted into an approved centre for treatment and rehabilitation.

    Sir, inhalant abusers may voluntarily undergo treatment and rehabilitation. A person who has been admitted to an approved centre may be detained in the centre for not more than six months and for subsequent periods of not more than three months at any one time, subject to a maximum period of one year's detention. Review Committees will be appointed to monitor the progress of inmates and may also order the early discharge of an inmate. The Bill also provides for safeguards against improper detention.
